segment_text: Impossible!

segment_text: But what is worship?

segment_text: To do the will of God?

segment_text: That is worship.

segment_text: And what is the will of God?

segment_text: To do to my fellow man what I would have my fellow man to do to me.

segment_text: That is the will of God.

segment_text: Now, Queequeg is my fellow man.
image_prompt: A dimly lit Spouter Inn room, a cracked stone hearth casting wavering shadows. segment_text: And what do I wish that this Queequeg would do to me?
image_prompt: A lone, darkened inn room, a crackling hearth and the scent of stormy sea outside. segment_text: Why, unite with me in my particular Presbyterian form of worship.
image_prompt: Ishmael, cloaked in a dimly lit cabin, holds an open Bible beside a flickering hearth; his face is illuminated by the flame as he whispers, “Why, unite with me in my particular Presbyterian form of worship.” Queequeg’s shadowy silhouette looms at the doorway, eyes fixed on the man. segment_text: Consequently, I must then unite with him in his, ergo I must turn idolater.

segment_text: So I kindled the shavings, helped prop up the innocent little idol, offered him burnt biscuit with kwee kweg, salamed before him twice or thrice, kissed his nose, and that done, we undressed and went to bed, at peace with our own consciences and all the world.
image_prompt: Ishmael in a dim, soot‑stained inn room, his hand igniting fine wood shavings that cast flickering shadows on a weathered wooden altar. segment_text: But we did not go to sleep without some little chat.

segment_text: How it is I know not, but there is no place like a bed for confidential disclosures between friends.

segment_text: Man and wife, they say, they're open the very bottom of their souls to each other, and some old couples often lie and chat over old times till nearly morning.
